title: LOCK_WAIT_HISTORY view | Snowflake Documentation
paragraphs:
This Account Usage view includes the history of transactions that wait on locks.
For details, see Analyzing blocked transactions with the LOCK_WAIT_HISTORY view.
Internal/system-generated identifier for the blocking object (such as a table) on which the transaction is waiting for a lock.
Type of lock. Valid values are PARTITION, STREAM, TABLE, and ROW. ROW is shown for hybrid table locks.
Identifier for the object (such as a table) on which the transaction is waiting for a lock. ROW is shown for hybrid table locks.
Internal/system-generated identifier for the schema of the object on which the transaction is waiting for a lock. 0 is shown for hybrid tables.
Identifier for the schema of the object on which the transaction is waiting for a lock. NULL is shown for ROW locks.
Internal/system-generated identifier for the database of the object on which the transaction is waiting for a lock.
Identifier for the database of the object on which the transaction is waiting for a lock.
Internal/system-generated identifier for the SQL statement that is waiting on the lock.

Internal/system-generated identifier for the transaction with the statement that is waiting on the lock. Can be joined with the QUERY_HISTORY view for additional details about the statements in the transaction.
Timestamp when the lock was requested by the transaction waiting for the lock.
Timestamp when the lock was acquired by the transaction holding the lock.

JSON array of objects. Each object is a blocker query with the following properties: 
.
is_snowflake: TRUE if the query is a background process run by Snowflake (e.g., automatic maintenance of materialized views). .
query_id: Query ID of the current statement in the blocker transaction that blocked the statement. Empty if is_snowflake is true. .
transaction_id: ID of the blocker transaction. Empty if is_snowflake is true. .
There may be up to 20 objects in this array.

The first blocker query ID that is returned in the blocker_queries array is the ID of the query that was being executed
in the transaction that holds the lock when the transaction waiting for the lock started waiting.
Note that it is possible that queries prior to that query in the blocker transaction also acquired the lock and should be investigated.

Each row in the output represents a transaction waiting on a lock. Note that there may be other transactions ahead
of that transaction, waiting on the same lock.
Find all the blocked transactions that requested locks within the past 24 hours:
For additional examples, see Analyzing blocked transactions with the LOCK_WAIT_HISTORY view.
